title: I'm out of the loop, did someone stomp with Poppy in pro play?
body:
Her popularity hasn't gone up a significant amount, so that doesn't seem likely. I'd just like an explanation for nerfs on a champion who's been somewhere below 35th in top lane for the last five patches, and below 50% in winrate even with an almost mains-only play rate for double that time. 

Edit: I'm glad to see that for once I actually got Red responses, but the response "we've been wanting to do these changes for a while" isn't an explanation. It may have been, if these changes were implemented along with Poppy's original nerfs back when she was wrongfully blamed for Courage of the Colossus's overpowered nature. But as of now, when she has been weak for many months following the tank item nerfs, they weren't warranted. 

If anything, Poppy was in need of the playmaking buff to the snapcast on her R with no compensatory nerfs to other abilities. THEN it should have been decided whether or not she was too tanky/fast to have a low-aoe 0.75s knockup with the base damage of a single adc auto attack.

Champions mains are not always an unbiased source of great feedback. Oftentimes champion mains main a champion because they are in love with the gameplay that currently exists and are resilient to any type of change. I am an Anivia main (and have been since ~2011). When we reworked Anivia so that she could not simply R-> E targets and nuke them while buffing her R and W, anivia mains constantly pmed me and told me that the changes were going to kill the champion, she'd be unplayable garbage, and that me and the designer had no idea how much we were dumpstering the champion. 

Anivia promptly rose to be one of the highest winrate mid laners for a large amount of time before nerfs/meta shifts/etc.

I feel it's possible to believe that changes can be a net negative regardless of whether they make the champion weak or strong.

For Anivia as an example, I was never an Anivia main, but I did dabble in her from time to time. I will never play her current incarnation because it honestly just isn't as satisfying as the old one. Too slow, too clunky, not reliable enough, and too much focus on control to the detriment of burst. To me it doesn't matter if she's more effective if her gameplay fantasy is changed for the worse. That's of course a non-main's perspective, but I think most mains will feel the same way even if they don't necessarily articulate it.

Sure -- I was speaking mostly from power here. I believe that champion feeling in terms of inputs/outputs is an area where listening to that kind of subjective feedback is very important.

I can understand being turned off Anivia from those changes, but at the end of the day my job is to make LoL a better holistic game -- and that's an example off the top of my head where I believe we succeeded despite outcry that we were dumpstering the champion.

Do you think that LoL is a better game, holistically, than it was a year ago?

One thing I’ve always been very curious to hear from Rioters is a real state of the game - not just how this aspect or that aspect is right now but how Riot thinks the game is doing compared to previous times. It’s something we usually only  get indirectly if a rework is reverted or through an aside in patch notes. 

I’ll be honest and admit I don’t enjoy the game as a whole as much today as I did a year ago. But it would be nice to hear a bit of more a very high level state of the game with comparisons to past experiences if just for players to be able to better understand Riot objectives in making changes. “We want to make X role stronger/weaker” is more informative in relation to a point in time - “We want to make X role return to the level of influence it had during Season Z”

If a main presents their views and feedback in a neutral way with a hope for constructive conversation would you be more open? I play Ashe but so try not to be biased since I know she's a less thought of champion but also walks the line of too strong or too weak because she has utility.

Would you want main feedback if we just tried to remove as much bias as possible?

It's not that I'm closed to champion main feedback at all! I often rely on information for mains when I'm communicating with designers about champions I'm not familiar with, for example. They're an incredibly useful resource when learning stuff about LoL, as each character is so deep that it's a fool's errand to pretend as if I know everything. 

Presenting feedback in a more neutral/constructive manner is always better to convey your point. This applies to us playtesters internally as well.

Yeah it's not shocking but do you blame them? They want to play the champion and game they signed up for. I still miss my AP Kog from S4. They don't want it to be turned into something else they don't enjoy when it's perfectly functional as is. 

What if I really liked chess and when I sign up for a chess tournament I find out that it's actually for checkers and mislabeled? This game has no stability and it feels bad to invest serious time into understanding it, maining some champs, finding your favorite items and builds or even your favorite role. 

Every few months you guys make all of this investment nearly worthless. Even after you do supposed reworks or item changes, they get rehashed another dozen times so there's zero trust that I will still have the game I enjoy, the items I want, etc. in another few months. Any normal game like poker, tennis, Starcraft (much more mechanically intense though) etc. I can have some confidence that my investment isn't flushed down the toilet every few months. 

I know there are some problems now and there's a lot of work to still do on this game for various champs, roles, items etc. but I hope there's some sort of end in sight for the frequency of high impact changes. Fix what you need. Change what you need but eventually let me actually enjoy a balanced game where I can find my preferences instead of being at the whim of the meta forced by so many nonstop changes. The game wasn't changing this radically all the time even from S4 to S5 when I was really getting into it. 

Once things are more settled, let the meta develop more organically and step in only if it's clear certain strategies are out of line or severely underperforming. If next year is going to continue to be this disruptive, I don't think I can take it seriously and invest so much time anymore. It fees like I'm punished for caring and studying the game. This applies to [chat too](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/player-behavior-moderation/0JIhtyBM-the-trolls-have-won-and-are-immune-to-criticism-punish-the-victims-instead).
Of course I don't blame them -- I just don't think that listening to champion mains solves all of our problems which is touted here frequently :)

Well, I can only agree so far as that mindset pertains to champions with a play rate above mains-only. Yes, it's the right decision  not to listen to champion mains when it's a popular champion who is doing too well. But when it's a <3% playrate champion who is doing poorly, ignoring the mains makes little sense.
The question is then WHY does the champion have such a low playrate? Without changes that champion is NEVER going to get picked by more people.
So... nerfs that make a champ weaker are gonna make more people pick them and totally not toss them to the wayside for other more powerful champs?

The other guy who responded to your comment hit the nail on the head. How would nerfs to a champion which don't change that champion's playstyle increase popularity?

If it were a nerf/buff combo which actually edited her playstyle somehow, you'd have a leg to stand on. But they don't. They specifically stated themselves that they want to force her into only doing one thing, which she already did, while taking away her ability to be safe at the mid-range of a teamfight after her E-- safe compared to no one except juggernauts who heal themselves because of their short range.

Honest, my gut reaction reading this was "it's a load of horsecrap". But I'll try to be a bit more constructive than that.

I'll start with the one point where I agree: yes, if you're enjoying a single champ with a single specific playstyle, you've no guarantee that they'll keep the same for a long time. And yes, even though it's not my case, I do understand that it's painful and frustrating. That would actually be a reason for me to leave the game.

But you don't HAVE TO main a single champ with a single playstyle. You can main a same champ through different meta and adapt to different playstyles. Even something as simple as Garen of all things has gone through 3 or 4 main builds over the last 2 years, and it can be fun exploring and learning even after hundreds of games on a champ. It can also be fun exploring and innovating and beating people thanks to your innovation. **Things changing is not necessarily a negative.**

And things changing doesn't mean your "investment is flushed down the drain", that's just a plain, gross exaggeration. If the build you mained is nerfed or fall out of flavor, there is still another build taking its place, and as a main of your champion, you should have a much easier time adapting to it than someone who's just trying to pick up the new flavor of the month.
Likewise if it's the champion who's affected instead of the build. If you played a Juggernaut or an ADC or a Burst Mage to hell and back, even if they are reworked and you don't enjoy them anymore, you should have an easy time picking up another Juggernaut, ADC or Burst Mage that you enjoy more and that you'll learn pretty quickly based on your experience with similar champs.

And on top of all that, whatever the champ you're playing, LoL strategies and macro-play principles always stay the same, and if you master it, it will stay with you no matter what champ you end up picking. Saying that LoL 8.10 is to LoL 5.7 or whatever what checkers is to chess is a ridiculous analogy. The details change all the time, but the core of the game is always the same.

Also, the game wasn't changing as much in S4 / S5? That's rose-tainted glasses right there, you might wanna re-read the Patch notes of that time. I barely had learned the S4 Jungle that it changed all over again in S5. The game was *always* changing.

I'm not really a fan of her snap cast ult. It doesn't _feel_ like an ultimate ability. It's a simple 0.75 second knock up on a really long cool down with incredibly low damage.

I think there should be a decision process involved in choosing to either fully charge her ult or snap cast it. Currently the decision is to either use a real ultimate ability or to use a budget Alistar/Aatrox Q that does 100 damage on a 140 second cool down. That doesn't feel good to use; it feels like you're trolling when you snap cast it.

In closing, I think ults should feel impactful and distinct from basic abilities. In my opinion, Poppy's snap cast does not fit either category.

My question is why the change was overall nerfs, with range buffs disguised as compensation. The explanation we got on the patch note was that the goal was to give her more strength on the things she can only do once a fight starts in exchange for the losses on higher-duration/passive aspects of her W. But the changes weren't buffs to the damage of her passive or the duration/damage of her E, but rather the ranges of both.

And while I'll concede that a range buff to the E does follow that line of reasoning, the loss of movement speed on the W makes it so that it is far more difficult to get within that range in the first place. As for the passive, it directly contradicts that line of reasoning, as the nerf hinges on the idea that she should be in the thick of combat. But giving her no damage increase/scaling on the passive, opting instead for a slight buff in range doesn't actually do anything unless you want to cheese norms with a rapid firecannon Poppy.

I think she still needs to be stronger than that even, shes very weak for a top lane right now. And while she can (barely) tank, she can't dmg top or play support as either role. It's too easy to zone her right now and her ult is a good disengage but that is pretty much all shes working with
